por.por_cntn:
Funding from this grant was for the acquisition of an IDS Stream X Multiple Array Ground Penetrating Radar unit and a Leica Scanstation C-10. The IDS Stream is a multiple array instrument in which the radar array is comprised of several antenna/receiver pairs. Multiple lines of data are acquired simultaneously as the array moves along the surface. As objects come into view, their shape, size and position can clearly be seen. The Leica Scanstation is an effective pulsed scanner, in a compact platform. This all-in-one scanner's capabilities give users the advantage of high-accuracy, long range scanning plus the advantage of fast, full dome interior scanning.

On of the primary objectives for this grant was to provide training to both graduate and undergraduate students. This equipment was introduced to students in an Archaeological Geophysics class. The Leica has been or is being used by two graduate students as part of their thesis project and one undergraduate student as part of her McNair Scholar Honors project. Jonathan Crise has used the scanner to record and identify an industrial complex in Fayette County, PA. Marion Smeltzer has completed on initial scan of remnant structures at the Allegheny Portage Railroad National Historic Park in Pennsylvania. Sarah LaFevre has completed an internal and external scan of the Altman Mill, a contributing element to the Saltsburg National Register Historic District in Pennsylvania. Students under the direction of Dr. R.Scott Moore completed scans of a Late Roman Basilica in Polis, Cyprus and an Archaic tomb in Atheinou, Cyprus. Jonathan Crise also completed a scan of an historic bridge as part of a pilot project with the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation to preserve architectural data and develop public programs. Two Geoscience students, Mike Barber and Drew Yetter under the direction of Dr. Nick Deardorff completed scans of the Mokst Butte lava flow in central Oregon. The IDS Stream will be used by graduate student David Breitkreutz under the direction of Dr. William Chadwick as part of his thesis integrating ground penetrating radar results with previously collected Leica Scanstation data.

A second objective was to disseminate information about the use and availability of the instruments. A workshop on the IDS Stream was presented at the National Park Service Archaeological Prospection Workshop, May 19-23, 2014. Approximately 40 attendees, representing federal and state agencies, Native American tribes, and universities were present at the workshop. A workshop on the Leica Scanstation was presented at the joint meeting of the National Alliance of Preservation Commissions and the Pennsylvania Statewide Conference on Heritage, July 16, 2014. The day long workshop introduced 21 participants to the basics of 3D laser scanning. A demonstration on the combined use of the IDS Stream and Leica Scanstation was presented at the 44th Annual Mid-Atlantic Archaeological Conference, March 14, 2014.

A blog was published on the use of the Leica for creating virtual worlds as venues for public archaeology. This was part of the Society for Historical Archaeology's week long series on Public Archaeology in January 2014.

A paper and poster were presented at the 79th Annual Meeting of the Society for American Archaeology in Austin, TX, April, 2014. A poster was presented at the 93rd Annual Meeting of the Transportation Research Board in Washington, D.C., January 13, 2014.

A third objective was to use the instruments in data collection, historic preservation and research activities. Additional completed data collection projects include: A Leica scan of Sutton Hall, a historic structure on the IUP campus; an IDS Stream survey of a parking lot on the IUP campus which is the site of a 19th to early 20th century glassworks; and an IDS Stream survey of the prehistoric site at Aztalan State Park in WIsconsin....
